command.name: help
command.description: Displays help for a command
command.help:
The <info>help</info> command displays help for a given command:
<info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console help list</info>
You can also output the help in other formats by using the <comment>--format</comment> option:
<info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console help --format=xml list</info>
To display the list of available commands, please use the <info>list</info> command.

option.name: --format
option.description: The output format (txt, xml, json, or md)

option.name: --verbose
option.description: Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug

option.name: --no-interaction
option.description: Do not ask any interactive question

option.name: --process-isolation
option.description: Launch commands from shell as a separate process.

command.name: list
command.description: Lists commands
command.help:
The <info>list</info> command lists all commands:
<info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console list</info>
You can also display the commands for a specific namespace:
<info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console list test</info>
You can also output the information in other formats by using the <comment>--format</comment> option:
<info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console list --format=xml</info>
It's also possible to get raw list of commands (useful for embedding command runner):
<info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console list --raw</info>

option.name: --format
option.description: The output format (txt, xml, json, or md)

command.name: assets:install
command.description: Installs bundles web assets under a public web directory
command.help:
The <info>assets:install</info> command installs bundle assets into a given directory (e.g. the <comment>web</comment> directory).
<info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console assets:install web</info>
A "bundles" directory will be created inside the target directory and the "Resources/public" directory of each bundle will be copied into it.
To create a symlink to each bundle instead of copying its assets, use the <info>--symlink</info> option (will fall back to hard copies when symbolic links aren't possible:
<info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console assets:install web --symlink</info>
To make symlink relative, add the <info>--relative</info> option:
<info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console assets:install web --symlink --relative</info>

option.name: --symlink
option.description: Symlinks the assets instead of copying it

option.name: --verbose
option.description: Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug

option.name: --no-interaction
option.description: Do not ask any interactive question

option.name: --process-isolation
option.description: Launch commands from shell as a separate process.

command.name: cache:clear
command.description: Clears the cache
command.help:
The <info>cache:clear</info> command clears the application cache for a given environment and debug mode:
<info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console cache:clear --env=dev</info> <info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console cache:clear --env=prod --no-debug</info>

option.name: --no-warmup
option.description: Do not warm up the cache

option.name: --verbose
option.description: Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug

option.name: --no-interaction
option.description: Do not ask any interactive question

option.name: --process-isolation
option.description: Launch commands from shell as a separate process.

command.name: cache:warmup
command.description: Warms up an empty cache
command.help:
The <info>cache:warmup</info> command warms up the cache.
Before running this command, the cache must be empty.
This command does not generate the classes cache (as when executing this command, too many classes that should be part of the cache are already loaded in memory). Use <comment>curl</comment> or any other similar tool to warm up the classes cache if you want.

option.name: --verbose
option.description: Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug

option.name: --no-interaction
option.description: Do not ask any interactive question

option.name: --process-isolation
option.description: Launch commands from shell as a separate process.

command.name: config:dump-reference
command.description: Dumps the default configuration for an extension
command.help:
The <info>config:dump-reference</info> command dumps the default configuration for an extension/bundle.
Either the extension alias or bundle name can be used:
<info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console config:dump-reference framework</info> <info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console config:dump-reference FrameworkBundle</info>
With the <info>--format</info> option specifies the format of the configuration, this is either <comment>yaml</comment> or <comment>xml</comment>. When the option is not provided, <comment>yaml</comment> is used.
<info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console config:dump-reference FrameworkBundle --format=xml</info>

argument.name: name
argument.description: The Bundle name or the extension alias

option.name: --verbose
option.description: Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug

option.name: --no-interaction
option.description: Do not ask any interactive question

option.name: --process-isolation
option.description: Launch commands from shell as a separate process.

command.name: debug:config
command.description: Dumps the current configuration for an extension
command.help:
The <info>debug:config</info> command dumps the current configuration for an extension/bundle.
Either the extension alias or bundle name can be used:
<info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console debug:config framework</info> <info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console debug:config FrameworkBundle</info>

argument.name: name
argument.description: The bundle name or the extension alias

command.name: debug:container
command.description: Displays current services for an application
command.help:
The <info>debug:container</info> command displays all configured <comment>public</comment> services:
<info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console debug:container</info>
To get specific information about a service, specify its name:
<info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console debug:container validator</info>
By default, private services are hidden. You can display all services by using the <info>--show-private</info> flag:
<info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console debug:container --show-private</info>
Use the --tags option to display tagged <comment>public</comment> services grouped by tag:
<info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console debug:container --tags</info>
Find all services with a specific tag by specifying the tag name with the <info>--tag</info> option:
<info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console debug:container --tag=form.type</info>
Use the <info>--parameters</info> option to display all parameters:
<info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console debug:container --parameters</info>
Display a specific parameter by specifying his name with the <info>--parameter</info> option:
<info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console debug:container --parameter=kernel.debug</info>

option.name: --show-private
option.description: Used to show public *and* private services

option.name: --tag
option.description: Shows all services with a specific tag

option.name: --tags
option.description: Displays tagged services for an application

option.name: --parameter
option.description: Displays a specific parameter for an application

option.name: --format

To get specific listeners for an event, specify its name:

command.name: debug:translation
command.description: Displays translation messages information
command.help:
The <info>debug:translation</info> command helps finding unused or missing translation messages and comparing them with the fallback ones by inspecting the templates and translation files of a given bundle or the app folder.
You can display information about bundle translations in a specific locale:
<info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console debug:translation en AcmeDemoBundle</info>
You can also specify a translation domain for the search:
<info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console debug:translation --domain=messages en AcmeDemoBundle</info>
You can only display missing messages:
<info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console debug:translation --only-missing en AcmeDemoBundle</info>
You can only display unused messages:
<info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console debug:translation --only-unused en AcmeDemoBundle</info>
You can display information about app translations in a specific locale:
<info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console debug:translation en</info>

argument.name: bundle
argument.description: The bundle name or directory where to load the messages, defaults to app/Resources folder

option.name: --verbose
option.description: Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug

option.name: --no-interaction
option.description: Do not ask any interactive question

option.name: --process-isolation
option.description: Launch commands from shell as a separate process.

command.name: debug:twig
command.description: Shows a list of twig functions, filters, globals and tests
command.help:
The <info>debug:twig</info> command outputs a list of twig functions, filters, globals and tests. Output can be filtered with an optional argument.
<info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console debug:twig</info>
The command lists all functions, filters, etc.
<info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console debug:twig date</info>
The command lists everything that contains the word date.
<info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console debug:twig --format=json</info>
The command lists everything in a machine readable json format.

argument.name: filter
argument.description: Show details for all entries matching this filter

command.name: doctrine:cache:clear-metadata
command.description: Clears all metadata cache for an entity manager
command.help:
The <info>doctrine:cache:clear-metadata</info> command is meant to clear the metadata cache of associated Entity Manager. It is possible to invalidate all cache entries at once - called delete -, or flushes the cache provider instance completely.
The execution type differ on how you execute the command. If you want to invalidate the entries (and not delete from cache instance), this command would do the work:
<info>doctrine:cache:clear-metadata</info>
Alternatively, if you want to flush the cache provider using this command:
<info>doctrine:cache:clear-metadata --flush</info>
Finally, be aware that if <info>--flush</info> option is passed, not all cache providers are able to flush entries, because of a limitation of its execution nature.

option.name: --flush
option.description: If defined, cache entries will be flushed instead of deleted/invalidated.

option.name: --em
option.description: The entity manager to use for this command

option.name: --verbose
option.description: Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug

option.name: --no-interaction
option.description: Do not ask any interactive question

option.name: --process-isolation
option.description: Launch commands from shell as a separate process.

command.name: doctrine:cache:clear-query
command.description: Clears all query cache for an entity manager
command.help:
The <info>doctrine:cache:clear-query</info> command is meant to clear the query cache of associated Entity Manager. It is possible to invalidate all cache entries at once - called delete -, or flushes the cache provider instance completely.
The execution type differ on how you execute the command. If you want to invalidate the entries (and not delete from cache instance), this command would do the work:
<info>doctrine:cache:clear-query</info>
Alternatively, if you want to flush the cache provider using this command:
<info>doctrine:cache:clear-query --flush</info>
Finally, be aware that if <info>--flush</info> option is passed, not all cache providers are able to flush entries, because of a limitation of its execution nature.

option.name: --flush
option.description: If defined, cache entries will be flushed instead of deleted/invalidated.

option.name: --em
option.description: The entity manager to use for this command

command.name: doctrine:cache:clear-result
command.description: Clears result cache for an entity manager
command.help:
The <info>doctrine:cache:clear-result</info> command is meant to clear the result cache of associated Entity Manager. It is possible to invalidate all cache entries at once - called delete -, or flushes the cache provider instance completely.
The execution type differ on how you execute the command. If you want to invalidate the entries (and not delete from cache instance), this command would do the work:
<info>doctrine:cache:clear-result</info>
Alternatively, if you want to flush the cache provider using this command:
<info>doctrine:cache:clear-result --flush</info>
Finally, be aware that if <info>--flush</info> option is passed, not all cache providers are able to flush entries, because of a limitation of its execution nature.

option.name: --flush
option.description: If defined, cache entries will be flushed instead of deleted/invalidated.

option.description: The entity manager to use for this command

command.name: doctrine:database:create
command.description: Creates the configured database
command.help:
The <info>doctrine:database:create</info> command creates the default connections database:
<info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console doctrine:database:create</info>
You can also optionally specify the name of a connection to create the database for:
<info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console doctrine:database:create --connection=default</info>

option.name: --connection
option.description: The connection to use for this command

option.description: Don't trigger an error, when the database already exists

command.name: doctrine:database:drop
command.description: Drops the configured database
command.help:
The <info>doctrine:database:drop</info> command drops the default connections database:
<info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console doctrine:database:drop</info>
The <info>--force</info> parameter has to be used to actually drop the database.
You can also optionally specify the name of a connection to drop the database for:
<info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console doctrine:database:drop --connection=default</info>
<error>Be careful: All data in a given database will be lost when executing this command.</error>

option.name: --connection
option.description: The connection to use for this command

option.name: --if-exists
option.description: Don't trigger an error, when the database doesn't exist

command.name: doctrine:generate:crud
command.description: Generates a CRUD based on a Doctrine entity
command.help:
The <info>doctrine:generate:crud</info> command generates a CRUD based on a Doctrine entity.
The default command only generates the list and show actions.
<info>php app/console doctrine:generate:crud --entity=AcmeBlogBundle:Post --route-prefix=post_admin</info>
Using the --with-write option allows to generate the new, edit and delete actions.
<info>php app/console doctrine:generate:crud --entity=AcmeBlogBundle:Post --route-prefix=post_admin --with-write</info>
Every generated file is based on a template. There are default templates but they can be overridden by placing custom templates in one of the following locations, by order of priority:
<info>BUNDLE_PATH/Resources/SensioGeneratorBundle/skeleton/crud APP_PATH/Resources/SensioGeneratorBundle/skeleton/crud</info>
And
<info>__bundle_path__/Resources/SensioGeneratorBundle/skeleton/form __project_root__/app/Resources/SensioGeneratorBundle/skeleton/form</info>
You can check https://github.com/sensio/SensioGeneratorBundle/tree/master/Resources/skeleton in order to know the file structure of the skeleton

argument.name: entity
argument.description: The entity class name to initialize (shortcut notation)

option.name: --entity
option.description: The entity class name to initialize (shortcut notation)

option.name: --with-write
option.description: Whether or not to generate create, new and delete actions

option.name: --format
option.description: Use the format for configuration files (php, xml, yml, or annotation)

option.name: --overwrite
option.description: Do not stop the generation if crud controller already exist, thus overwriting all generated files

option.name: --verbose
option.description: Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug

option.name: --no-interaction
option.description: Do not ask any interactive question

option.name: --process-isolation
option.description: Launch commands from shell as a separate process.

command.name: doctrine:generate:entities
command.description: Generates entity classes and method stubs from your mapping information
command.help:
The <info>doctrine:generate:entities</info> command generates entity classes and method stubs from your mapping information:
You have to limit generation of entities:
* To a bundle:
<info>php app/console doctrine:generate:entities MyCustomBundle</info>
* To a single entity:
<info>php app/console doctrine:generate:entities MyCustomBundle:User</info> <info>php app/console doctrine:generate:entities MyCustomBundle/Entity/User</info>
* To a namespace
<info>php app/console doctrine:generate:entities MyCustomBundle/Entity</info>
If the entities are not stored in a bundle, and if the classes do not exist, the command has no way to guess where they should be generated. In this case, you must provide the <comment>--path</comment> option:
<info>php app/console doctrine:generate:entities Blog/Entity --path=src/</info>
By default, the unmodified version of each entity is backed up and saved (e.g. Product.php~). To prevent this task from creating the backup file, pass the <comment>--no-backup</comment> option:
<info>php app/console doctrine:generate:entities Blog/Entity --no-backup</info>
<error>Important:</error> Even if you specified Inheritance options in your XML or YAML Mapping files the generator cannot generate the base and child classes for you correctly, because it doesn't know which class is supposed to extend which. You have to adjust the entity code manually for inheritance to work!

argument.name: name
argument.description: A bundle name, a namespace, or a class name

option.name: --path
option.description: The path where to generate entities when it cannot be guessed

option.name: --no-backup
option.description: Do not backup existing entities files.

option.name: --verbose
option.description: Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug

option.name: --no-interaction
option.description: Do not ask any interactive question

option.name: --process-isolation
option.description: Launch commands from shell as a separate process.

command.name: doctrine:generate:entity
command.description: Generates a new Doctrine entity inside a bundle
command.help:
The <info>doctrine:generate:entity</info> task generates a new Doctrine entity inside a bundle:
<info>php app/console doctrine:generate:entity --entity=AcmeBlogBundle:Blog/Post</info>
The above command would initialize a new entity in the following entity namespace <info>Acme\BlogBundle\Entity\Blog\Post</info>.
You can also optionally specify the fields you want to generate in the new entity:
<info>php app/console doctrine:generate:entity --entity=AcmeBlogBundle:Blog/Post --fields="title:string(255) body:text"</info>
The command can also generate the corresponding entity repository class with the <comment>--with-repository</comment> option:
<info>php app/console doctrine:generate:entity --entity=AcmeBlogBundle:Blog/Post --with-repository</info>
By default, the command uses annotations for the mapping information; change it with <comment>--format</comment>:
<info>php app/console doctrine:generate:entity --entity=AcmeBlogBundle:Blog/Post --format=yml</info>
To deactivate the interaction mode, simply use the `--no-interaction` option without forgetting to pass all needed options:
<info>php app/console doctrine:generate:entity --entity=AcmeBlogBundle:Blog/Post --format=annotation --fields="title:string(255) body:text" --with-repository --no-interaction</info>

option.name: --entity
option.description: The entity class name to initialize (shortcut notation)

option.name: --fields
option.description: The fields to create with the new entity

option.name: --format
option.description: Use the format for configuration files (php, xml, yml, or annotation)

option.name: --with-repository
option.description: Whether to generate the entity repository or not

option.name: --verbose
option.description: Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug

option.name: --no-interaction
option.description: Do not ask any interactive question

option.name: --process-isolation
option.description: Launch commands from shell as a separate process.

command.name: doctrine:generate:form
command.description: Generates a form type class based on a Doctrine entity
command.help:
The <info>doctrine:generate:form</info> command generates a form class based on a Doctrine entity.
<info>php app/console doctrine:generate:form AcmeBlogBundle:Post</info>
Every generated file is based on a template. There are default templates but they can be overriden by placing custom templates in one of the following locations, by order of priority:
<info>BUNDLE_PATH/Resources/SensioGeneratorBundle/skeleton/form APP_PATH/Resources/SensioGeneratorBundle/skeleton/form</info>
You can check https://github.com/sensio/SensioGeneratorBundle/tree/master/Resources/skeleton in order to know the file structure of the skeleton

argument.name: entity
argument.description: The entity class name to initialize (shortcut notation)

option.name: --verbose
option.description: Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug

option.name: --no-interaction
option.description: Do not ask any interactive question

option.name: --process-isolation
option.description: Launch commands from shell as a separate process.

command.name: doctrine:mapping:convert
command.description: Convert mapping information between supported formats.
command.help:
Convert mapping information between supported formats.
This is an execute <info>one-time</info> command. It should not be necessary for you to call this method multiple times, especially when using the <comment>--from-database</comment> flag.
Converting an existing database schema into mapping files only solves about 70-80% of the necessary mapping information. Additionally the detection from an existing database cannot detect inverse associations, inheritance types, entities with foreign keys as primary keys and many of the semantical operations on associations such as cascade.
<comment>Hint:</comment> There is no need to convert YAML or XML mapping files to annotations every time you make changes. All mapping drivers are first class citizens in Doctrine 2 and can be used as runtime mapping for the ORM.
<comment>Hint:</comment> If you have a database with tables that should not be managed by the ORM, you can use a DBAL functionality to filter the tables and sequences down on a global level:
$config->setFilterSchemaAssetsExpression($regexp);

argument.name: to-type
argument.description: The mapping type to be converted.

argument.name: dest-path
argument.description: The path to generate your entities classes.

option.name: --filter
option.description: A string pattern used to match entities that should be processed.

option.name: --force
option.description: Force to overwrite existing mapping files.

option.name: --from-database
option.description: Whether or not to convert mapping information from existing database.

option.name: --extend
option.description: Defines a base class to be extended by generated entity classes.

option.name: --num-spaces
option.description: Defines the number of indentation spaces

option.name: --namespace
option.description: Defines a namespace for the generated entity classes, if converted from database.

option.name: --em
option.description: The entity manager to use for this command

option.name: --verbose
option.description: Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug

option.name: --no-interaction
option.description: Do not ask any interactive question

option.name: --process-isolation
option.description: Launch commands from shell as a separate process.

command.name: doctrine:mapping:import
command.description: Imports mapping information from an existing database
command.help:
The <info>doctrine:mapping:import</info> command imports mapping information from an existing database:
<info>php app/console doctrine:mapping:import "MyCustomBundle" xml</info>
You can also optionally specify which entity manager to import from with the <info>--em</info> option:
<info>php app/console doctrine:mapping:import "MyCustomBundle" xml --em=default</info>
If you don't want to map every entity that can be found in the database, use the <info>--filter</info> option. It will try to match the targeted mapped entity with the provided pattern string.
<info>php app/console doctrine:mapping:import "MyCustomBundle" xml --filter=MyMatchedEntity</info>
Use the <info>--force</info> option, if you want to override existing mapping files:
<info>php app/console doctrine:mapping:import "MyCustomBundle" xml --force</info>

argument.name: bundle
argument.description: The bundle to import the mapping information to

argument.name: mapping-type
argument.description: The mapping type to export the imported mapping information to

option.name: --em
option.description: The entity manager to use for this command

option.name: --filter
option.description: A string pattern used to match entities that should be mapped.

option.name: --force
option.description: Force to overwrite existing mapping files.

option.name: --verbose
option.description: Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug

option.name: --no-interaction
option.description: Do not ask any interactive question

option.name: --process-isolation
option.description: Launch commands from shell as a separate process.

command.name: doctrine:query:dql
command.description: Executes arbitrary DQL directly from the command line.
command.help:
The <info>doctrine:query:dql</info> command executes the given DQL query and outputs the results:
<info>php app/console doctrine:query:dql "SELECT u FROM UserBundle:User u"</info>
You can also optional specify some additional options like what type of hydration to use when executing the query:
<info>php app/console doctrine:query:dql "SELECT u FROM UserBundle:User u" --hydrate=array</info>
Additionally you can specify the first result and maximum amount of results to show:
<info>php app/console doctrine:query:dql "SELECT u FROM UserBundle:User u" --first-result=0 --max-result=30</info>

option.name: --hydrate
option.description: Hydration mode of result set. Should be either: object, array, scalar or single-scalar.

option.name: --first-result
option.description: The first result in the result set.

option.name: --max-result
option.description: The maximum number of results in the result set.

option.name: --em
option.description: The entity manager to use for this command

option.name: --verbose
option.description: Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug

option.name: --no-interaction
option.description: Do not ask any interactive question

option.name: --process-isolation
option.description: Launch commands from shell as a separate process.

command.name: doctrine:query:sql
command.description: Executes arbitrary SQL directly from the command line.
command.help:
The <info>doctrine:query:sql</info> command executes the given SQL query and outputs the results:
<info>php app/console doctrine:query:sql "SELECT * from user"</info>

option.name: --connection

option.name: --dump-sql

option.name: --force
option.description: Don't ask for the deletion of the database, but force the operation to run.

option.name: --full-database
option.description: Instead of using the Class Metadata to detect the database table schema, drop ALL assets that the database contains.

option.name: --em

command.name: doctrine:schema:update
command.description: Executes (or dumps) the SQL needed to update the database schema to match the current mapping metadata.
command.help:
The <info>doctrine:schema:update</info> command generates the SQL needed to synchronize the database schema with the current mapping metadata of the default entity manager.
For example, if you add metadata for a new column to an entity, this command would generate and output the SQL needed to add the new column to the database:
<info>doctrine:schema:update --dump-sql</info>
Alternatively, you can execute the generated queries:
<info>doctrine:schema:update --force</info>
If both options are specified, the queries are output and then executed:
<info>doctrine:schema:update --dump-sql --force</info>
Finally, be aware that if the <info>--complete</info> option is passed, this task will drop all database assets (e.g. tables, etc) that are *not* described by the current metadata. In other words, without this option, this task leaves untouched any "extra" tables that exist in the database, but which aren't described by any metadata.
<comment>Hint:</comment> If you have a database with tables that should not be managed by the ORM, you can use a DBAL functionality to filter the tables and sequences down on a global level:
$config->setFilterSchemaAssetsExpression($regexp);

option.name: --complete
option.description: If defined, all assets of the database which are not relevant to the current metadata will be dropped.

option.name: --dump-sql
option.description: Dumps the generated SQL statements to the screen (does not execute them).

option.name: --force
option.description: Causes the generated SQL statements to be physically executed against your database.

option.name: --em
option.description: The entity manager to use for this command

option.name: --verbose
option.description: Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug

option.name: --no-interaction
option.description: Do not ask any interactive question

option.name: --process-isolation
option.description: Launch commands from shell as a separate process.

command.name: generate:bundle
command.description: Generates a bundle
command.help:
The <info>generate:bundle</info> command helps you generates new bundles.
By default, the command interacts with the developer to tweak the generation. Any passed option will be used as a default value for the interaction (<comment>--namespace</comment> is the only one needed if you follow the conventions):
<info>php app/console generate:bundle --namespace=Acme/BlogBundle</info>
Note that you can use <comment>/</comment> instead of <comment>\ </comment>for the namespace delimiter to avoid any problem.
If you want to disable any user interaction, use <comment>--no-interaction</comment> but don't forget to pass all needed options:
<info>php app/console generate:bundle --namespace=Acme/BlogBundle --dir=src [--bundle-name=...] --no-interaction</info>
Note that the bundle namespace must end with "Bundle".

option.name: --namespace
option.description: The namespace of the bundle to create

option.name: --dir
option.description: The directory where to create the bundle

option.name: --format
option.description: Use the format for configuration files (php, xml, yml, or annotation)

option.name: --structure
option.description: Whether to generate the whole directory structure

option.name: --verbose
option.description: Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug

option.name: --no-interaction
option.description: Do not ask any interactive question

option.name: --process-isolation
option.description: Launch commands from shell as a separate process.

command.name: generate:controller
command.description: Generates a controller
command.help:
The <info>generate:controller</info> command helps you generates new controllers inside bundles.
By default, the command interacts with the developer to tweak the generation. Any passed option will be used as a default value for the interaction (<comment>--bundle</comment> and <comment>--controller</comment> are the only ones needed if you follow the conventions):
<info>php app/console generate:controller --controller=AcmeBlogBundle:Post</info>
If you want to disable any user interaction, use <comment>--no-interaction</comment> but don't forget to pass all needed options:
<info>php app/console generate:controller --controller=AcmeBlogBundle:Post --no-interaction</info>
Every generated file is based on a template. There are default templates but they can be overriden by placing custom templates in one of the following locations, by order of priority:
<info>BUNDLE_PATH/Resources/SensioGeneratorBundle/skeleton/controller APP_PATH/Resources/SensioGeneratorBundle/skeleton/controller</info>
You can check https://github.com/sensio/SensioGeneratorBundle/tree/master/Resources/skeleton in order to know the file structure of the skeleton

option.name: --controller
option.description: The name of the controller to create

option.name: --route-format
option.description: The format that is used for the routing (yml, xml, php, annotation)

option.name: --template-format
option.description: The format that is used for templating (twig, php)

option.name: --verbose
option.description: Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug

option.name: --no-interaction
option.description: Do not ask any interactive question

option.name: --process-isolation
option.description: Launch commands from shell as a separate process.

command.name: init:acl
command.description: Mounts ACL tables in the database
command.help:
The <info>init:acl</info> command mounts ACL tables in the database.
<info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console init:acl</info>
The name of the DBAL connection must be configured in your <info>app/config/security.yml</info> configuration file in the <info>security.acl.connection</info> variable.
<info>security: acl: connection: default</info>

option.name: --verbose
option.description: Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug

option.name: --no-interaction
option.description: Do not ask any interactive question

option.name: --process-isolation
option.description: Launch commands from shell as a separate process.

command.name: lint:twig
command.description: Lints a template and outputs encountered errors
command.help:
The <info>lint:twig</info> command lints a template and outputs to STDOUT the first encountered syntax error.
You can validate the syntax of a file:
<info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console lint:twig filename</info>
Or of a whole directory:
<info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console lint:twig dirname</info> <info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console lint:twig dirname --format=json</info>
You can also pass the template contents from STDIN:
<info>cat filename | php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console lint:twig</info> Or all template files in a bundle:
<info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console lint:twig @AcmeDemoBundle</info>

option.name: --verbose
option.description: Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug

option.name: --no-interaction
option.description: Do not ask any interactive question

option.name: --process-isolation
option.description: Launch commands from shell as a separate process.

command.name: lint:yaml
command.description: Lints a file and outputs encountered errors
command.help:
The <info>lint:yaml</info> command lints a YAML file and outputs to STDOUT the first encountered syntax error.
You can validate the syntax of a file:
<info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console lint:yaml filename</info>
Or of a whole directory:
<info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console lint:yaml dirname</info> <info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console lint:yaml dirname --format=json</info>
Or all YAML files in a bundle:
<info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console lint:yaml @AcmeDemoBundle</info>
You can also pass the YAML contents from STDIN:
<info>cat filename | php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console lint:yaml</info>

argument.name: filename
argument.description: A file or a directory or STDIN

option.name: --verbose

option.description: Launch commands from shell as a separate process.

command.help:
The <info>router:dump-apache</info> dumps all routes as Apache rewrite rules. These can then be used with the ApacheUrlMatcher to use Apache for route matching.
<info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console router:dump-apache</info>

command.help:
The <info>router:match</info> shows which routes match a given request and which don't and for what reason:
<info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console router:match /foo</info>
or
<info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console router:match /foo --method POST --scheme https --host symfony.com --verbose</info>

option.name: --scheme
option.description: Sets the URI scheme (usually http or https)

command.name: security:check
command.description: Checks security issues in your project dependencies
command.help:
The <info>security:check</info> command looks for security issues in the project dependencies:
<info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console security:check</info>
You can also pass the path to a <info>composer.lock</info> file as an argument:
<info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console security:check /path/to/composer.lock</info>
By default, the command displays the result in plain text, but you can also configure it to output JSON instead by using the <info>--format</info> option:
<info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console security:check /path/to/composer.lock --format=json</info>

argument.name: lock
argument.description: The path to the composer.lock file

option.name: --verbose
option.description: Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug

option.name: --no-interaction
option.description: Do not ask any interactive question

option.name: --process-isolation
option.description: Launch commands from shell as a separate process.

command.name: security:encode-password
command.description: Encodes a password.
command.help:
The <info>security:encode-password</info> command encodes passwords according to your security configuration. This command is mainly used to generate passwords for the <comment>in_memory</comment> user provider type and for changing passwords in the database while developing the application.
Suppose that you have the following security configuration in your application:
<comment> # app/config/security.yml security: encoders: Symfony\Component\Security\Core\User\User: plaintext AppBundle\Entity\User: bcrypt </comment>
If you execute the command non-interactively, the default Symfony User class is used and a random salt is generated to encode the password:
<info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console security:encode-password --no-interaction [password]</info>
Pass the full user class path as the second argument to encode passwords for your own entities:
<info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console security:encode-password --no-interaction [password] AppBundle\Entity\User</info>
Executing the command interactively allows you to generate a random salt for encoding the password:
<info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console security:encode-password [password] AppBundle\Entity\User</info>
In case your encoder doesn't require a salt, add the <comment>empty-salt</comment> option:
<info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console security:encode-password --empty-salt [password] AppBundle\Entity\User</info>

argument.name: user-class
argument.description: The User entity class path associated with the encoder used to encode the password.

option.name: --empty-salt
option.description: Do not generate a salt or let the encoder generate one.

option.name: --verbose
option.description: Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug

option.name: --no-interaction
option.description: Do not ask any interactive question

option.name: --process-isolation
option.description: Launch commands from shell as a separate process.

command.name: server:run
command.description: Runs PHP built-in web server
command.help:
The <info>server:run</info> runs PHP built-in web server:
<info>/home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console server:run</info>
To change default bind address and port use the <info>address</info> argument:
<info>/home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console server:run 127.0.0.1:8080</info>
To change default docroot directory use the <info>--docroot</info> option:
<info>/home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console server:run --docroot=htdocs/</info>
If you have custom docroot directory layout, you can specify your own router script using <info>--router</info> option:
<info>/home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console server:run --router=app/config/router.php</info>
Specifing a router script is required when the used environment is not "dev", "prod", or "test".
See also: http://www.php.net/manual/en/features.commandline.webserver.php

option.name: --verbose
option.description: Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug

option.name: --no-interaction
option.description: Do not ask any interactive question

option.name: --process-isolation
option.description: Launch commands from shell as a separate process.

command.name: server:start
command.description: Starts PHP built-in web server in the background
command.help:
The <info>server:start</info> runs PHP's built-in web server:
<info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console server:start</info>
To change the default bind address and the default port use the <info>address</info> argument:
<info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console server:start 127.0.0.1:8080</info>
To change the default document root directory use the <info>--docroot</info> option:
<info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console server:start --docroot=htdocs/</info>
If you have a custom document root directory layout, you can specify your own router script using the <info>--router</info> option:
<info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console server:start --router=app/config/router.php</info>
Specifying a router script is required when the used environment is not <comment>"dev"</comment> or <comment>"prod"</comment>.
See also: http://www.php.net/manual/en/features.commandline.webserver.php

option.name: --verbose
option.description: Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug

option.name: --no-interaction
option.description: Do not ask any interactive question

option.name: --process-isolation
option.description: Launch commands from shell as a separate process.

The <info>server:stop</info> stops PHP's built-in web server:
<info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console server:stop</info>
To change the default bind address and the default port use the <info>address</info> argument:
<info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console server:stop 127.0.0.1:8080</info>

command.name: swiftmailer:email:send

usages.usage: swiftmailer:email:send [--from FROM] [--to TO] [--subject SUBJECT] [--body BODY] [--mailer MAILER] [--content-type CONTENT-TYPE] [--charset CHARSET] [--body-source BODY-SOURCE]

command.description: Send simple email message
command.help:
The <info>swiftmailer:email:send</info> command creates and send simple email message.
<info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console swiftmailer:email:send --mailer=custom_mailer --content-type=text/xml</info>
You can get body of message from file: <info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console swiftmailer:email:send --body-source=file --body=/path/to/file</info>

The <info>swiftmailer:spool:send</info> command sends all emails from the spool.
<info>php app/console swiftmailer:spool:send --message-limit=10 --time-limit=10 --recover-timeout=900 --mailer=default</info>

command.name: translation:update
command.description: Updates the translation file
command.help:
The <info>translation:update</info> command extract translation strings from templates of a given bundle or the app folder. It can display them or merge the new ones into the translation files. When new translation strings are found it can automatically add a prefix to the translation message.
Example running against a Bundle (AcmeBundle) <info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console translation:update --dump-messages en AcmeBundle</info> <info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console translation:update --force --prefix="new_" fr AcmeBundle</info>
Example running against app messages (app/Resources folder) <info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console translation:update --dump-messages en</info> <info>php /home/gapon/NetBeansProjects/symfony2/app/console translation:update --force --prefix="new_" fr</info>

argument.name: bundle
argument.description: The bundle name or directory where to load the messages, defaults to app/Resources folder

option.name: --dump-messages
option.description: Should the messages be dumped in the console

option.name: --verbose
option.description: Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug

option.name: --no-interaction
option.description: Do not ask any interactive question

option.name: --process-isolation
option.description: Launch commands from shell as a separate process.
